titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. IV:15. Monday
Petition from 352 females resident in Salem County New-Jersey for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia, with a Letter from Abigail Goodwin.
presented 3. Feby.
Mr De Wint called on me this morning; and went with me to the Capitol— After the reading of the Journal and the call for Petitions came, Hammond of South Carolina,
Rose too late—at the House— Motion made and carried by two thirds to suspend the Rules, to receive Petitions till one O’Clock, and Petitions were received from Virginia Northward to Pennsylvania—
3. VII. Wednesday
4. VI. Thursday.— Severe cold— Fahrenheit—

At the House— H. Pinckney moves a suspension of the rules of the House to move a Resolution for referring all the abolition Petitions, and Resolutions now before the House to a Select Committee with Instructions to make a long report, question taken by yeas and naystonot two thirds.
Motion by Cambreleng Mann of New-York, to suspend the rules to take up the report of the Select Committee on the Rules 102 to 103 not two thirds.

Orders of the day suspended to receive Reports from standing and select Committees— Reports accordingly made— I reported from the Committee of Manufactures unfavourably on the petition of the Georgia Union Company, to import two iron Steam boats free of duty and moved it should be laid on the Table—which was done—

The Bill making partial appropriations for 1836. was taken up and the motion for referring it to the Judiciary Committee, and to a select Committee with instructions to make the mileage of members uniform was debated and finally cut off by the previous Question which was carried, and the Bill was passed— After which, a motion was made and carried for a Committee of 24. one from each State, to settle a uniform rule of Mileage and to reduce the contingent expenses of the House— House adjourned at 3— I went into the Library and consulted the opinions of Deborah Wilkins, Alworthy’s old woman servant in Tom Jones— Evening at home, with the left eye much inflamed and yet forced to write as long as I could hold a pen—
5. VI. Friday. Fahrenheit

Inflammation of my eyes distressing. Visit from Dr Wainwright— He goes for Boston to-morow. Dr Huntt was here— I called on Mr Slade at his lodgings—Hyatt’s—He is confined to his chamber. I took with me the National Advocate from 18 to 30. Jany— At the House I found Hannegan moving a set of Instructions to the Committee of 24. yesterday ordered upon the mileage and attendance of members— He moved for a suspension of the rules, and after three or four motions and calls for yeas and nays the Motion was laid upon the table. Then came F. O. J. Smith’s Resolution to call up from the files of the last House, the Memorial of the last Postmaster General, against the two Reports of the Committee of the House— This was contested and debate, and the reading of the Memorial was called for and commenced— At the expiration of the hour the house passed to the order of the day—private business— A bill for the relief of Jesse Smith and others raised a debate of two hours.
6. VI:30. Saturday.
Call at the Department of War; with Letters from Antony Collamore of Pembroke in behalf of Elizabeth Gundaway,

Then at the Navy Department, where I left with Mr Dickerson, a Letter for Midshipman J. Q. Adams 2d. and spoke in behalf of Henry Kuhn, for a Midshipman’s warrant— He said he could not do that, but he would give an order for him to go to Port Mahon— I called at Mr Van Buren’s house, but he was not at home— Then at Fuller’s, where I saw Mr and Mrs A. H. Everett; and gave him a Letter from Doctor J. T. Kirkland.
7. VI:30. Sunday.
Snow— Heard at the Presbyterian Church,
8. VII. Monday.

Call at the Hall of the Senate, and requested the Papers in the Case of Ebenezer Lobdell— Mr J. Davis promised to have them taken from the files of the Senate, and sent to the House, which he afterwards did. At the House, immediately after the reading of the Journal, H. L. Pinckney asked the consent of the House to offer his Slavery Committee for the abolition of Petitions— Objection made— Pinckney moved the suspension of the Rule; carriedHe made a short speech, in support of his Resolution, and complained of a violent attack upon him in the Telegraph— He was answered vehemently by Hammond of South-Carolina— Then came a motion for the previous question, seconded, then a motion for a Call of the House, not sustained—and the previous question carried— After which Vinton of Ohio moved that the Resolution should be divided into three questions which gave rise to much debate on points of order—and two appeals from decisions of the Chair both of which were confirmed— Four questions were taken by yeas and nays on parcels of the Resolution, all carried by large Majorities— Wise refused to vote upon one division of the Resolution thinking he had no right to vote on it; and was excused— Rice Garland, asked leave to enter a Protest against part of the Resolution but he was not permitted.

A Message from the President informed the House that the Government of Great Britain had offered its Mediation, in the dispute with France, and that it had been accepted—referred to the Committee of Foreign Relations— Adjourned after 5. O’Clock— Weather moderated—
9. V:30. Tuesday.

Dr Lovell called upon me this Morning.—with a Subscription paper to call a Meeting of the Members of the Congregation of the 2d. Presbyterian Church, for the election of a Pastor— The object of the meeting is for the election of Mr Bishop—and I subscribed the paper. at the House Holsey of Georgia, moved a question, with a view subsequently to move a reconsideration of the Resolution yesterday moved by H. L. Pinckney and carried, but the Speaker declared Holsey’s motion not in order. Rice Garland of Louisiana, Glascock of Georgia, and Robertson of Virginia, moved a suspension of the Rules, to enable them to spread upon the Journal a protest against the vote of the House, to instruct the Committee on the Slavery Memorial to declare that Congress have not the power to interfere with Slavery in the States— The question of suspending the Rules was rejected by yeas and nays.

The House at the motion of Cambreleng went into Committee of the whole on the Union, Miller of Pennsylvania in the Chair upon the Navy Appropriation Bill— Cambreleng withdrew the amendment formerly proposed of two Millions for building and repairs of ships and Bell of Tennessee moved to reduced by one half, the appropriations for Navy-Yards—answered by Jarvis and Parker— Underwood and Dunlap opposed the appropriation and Pearce of Rhode-Island, Sutherland, Phillips and Cambreleng.
10. VI. Wednesday

Petition of Ebenezer Lobdell and Papers drawn from the files of the Senate referred at my Motion to the Committee of Claims— Rules suspended and the Bills from the Senate read first and second time and referred to the Committees of the whole— Reports from the Standing and Select Committees received— Motion of Ashley and Underwood to suspend the Rules to receive Resolutions and Petitions; not carried— After the expiration of the hour, the Speaker announced the orders of the day— The House went into Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union, on the Naval Appropriation Bill— Bell’s motion to reduce the Appropriation for the Navy-Yard at Portsmouth New-Hampshire from 67000 to 40,000, under consideration— Horace Everett will vote to reduce the appropriation because he is for abolishing all the Navy Yards excepting four; and that of Portsmouth is one of those to be abolished— He is against unnecessary tide-water appropriations. L. Lincoln in a set Speech supports the Appropriations— Everett declares his desires to distribute all the surplus revenues, to the States according to Clay’s Land Bill— D. J. Pearce moves the Committee should rise, intending to speak to-morrow— Hardin makes a speech against the appropriations generally—especially on the Seaboard— Committee rise. Adjourn at 4. O’Clock. I dined with M. Dickerson Secy. of the Navy— Vice-President M. Van Buren, and 20 others there— Foreign Chargés d’Affaires and Attachés—M’Keon, Donelson—Dickins—Major Macomb—Forsyth’s son &c— Conversation with Mr Van-Buren at table— Home between 8 and 9 in the Evening.
11. I:30: and IV. Thursday.

Awoke between one and two of the Morning, and immediately suffered severely with cramps in the right leg— I rose and after ascertaining the time of the Night returned to bed, and lay awake till four. Then rose; but my fire was extinct— I attempted without success to rekindle my fire; but read and wrote till after Sunrise without fire— I called at the office of the Secretary of the Treasury and ex
12. VII. Friday

Long Night’s rest, and some composure. Kervand came for the Letter to C. Hughes, which I had promised him— I was obliged to ask him to come again to-morrow— Call at Keyworth’s shop, and paid his Bill— At the House— D. J. Pearce shewed me the New-Hampshire Patriot, and Gorham Parks a New-York Transcript— Several attempts were made to suspend the Rules: one only succeeded—for a Resolution to appoint a Select Committee of 9. for extending the Pension Laws to Western Militia men who served in the Indian Wars from 1783 to 1795— Committee ordered— J. R. Ingersoll offered a Resolution for a bust of Chief Justice Marshall to be placed in the Hall of the Supreme Court At one the orders of the day were called— Private Bills— Bill for Relief ofMann, Hardin, Vanderpoel, Lewis Williams;
13. VI. Saturday.

Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures; five members present Dickerson, Judson, Granger and Webster—absent Denny, M’Comas, Gideon Lee and Holsey—a bare Quorum present— I read the Letter from the Secretary of State, J. Forsyth, with the Statement of Baron Roenne the Belgian Charge d’Affaires, claiming the abolition of the duties upon linen-tape— The opinion of the members was unanimous against the application—
14. V:30. Sunday

There was rain in the night, and then a brisk Northwester which spread a sheet of glass on the ground and made it impossible almost to walk— I attended at St. John’s Church where Mr Hawley read Prayers for Quinquagesima Sunday and preached from Proverbs 1.22. “How long ye simple ones will ye love simplicity? and the scorners delight in their scorning, and fools hate knowledge.” As I was coming out of Church, Mr Van Buren told me that a Messenger had this morning arrived with despatches, and information that the dispute with France was settled— That the Government of France, without waiting for the result of the Mediation had given notice that they would at once pay the money— Alexander H. Everett also called and had some conversation with me— He is in search of friends here; but whether they will be useful to him may be doubted. I received a second singular Letter from S. S. Southworth with the New-York Transcript of the 9th. and a Charleston Courier containing also a Letter from him concerning me. Mr Hawley’s afternoon Sermon was from Proverbs 16.18. “Pride goeth before destruction, and an haughty Spirit before a Fall.”— I was much affected this morning by reading the 71st. Psalm—a part of the service of the day— On returning home after Church this afternoon I found Mrs W. S. Smith here— I received a note from Mr Forsyth, Secretary of State enclosing a Letter of 6 Decr. last from C. Hughes at Stockholm—and giving me the same information which had been communicated to me by Mr Van Buren— Mrs Smith went home soon after dark, and I finished the draught for a closing Speech, upon my Resolution of enquiry into the causes of the loss of the fortification Bill— The Speech itself seems to have been rendered superfluous by the Settlement of the dispute with France.
15. V:30. Monday—

Returned to the Bedchamber.— Kervand came for the Letter from to C Hughes which I had promised him, and which I gave him— At the House several motions were made to dispense with the reading of the Journal, but without success— After the reading of the Journal, Franklin Pierce of New-Hampshire asked the permission of the House, to make a statement; upon which objection being made, he moved and carried the suspension; and made his Statement, which was an attack upon him in a New-Hampshire Newspaper, for an assertion made by him at an early day of the Session that not one person in 500 in New-Hampshire was in favour of the abolition of Slavery—which had been read by Mr Calhoun in the Senate— Pierce defended the accuracy of his former assertions, with severe remarks upon the Paper— After which Petitions were called for—and Briggs presented a Petition from the State of New-York, for the abolition of Slavery and the Slave trade in the District of Columbia— Wise objected to the receipt of the Petition, which the Speaker decided was in order and that the question was debatable—upon which Wise commenced a furious Slavery Speech, and speaking of H. L. Pinckney’s Resolution, said he hissed him as a Deserter from the principles of the South on the subject of Slavery. He was called to order and a snarling debate of two hours followed— It was finally decided by yeas and nays— That he was out of order—and then a motion was made that he should have permission to proceed which was granted 111. to 92. Then Vinton made a point of order; whether after the adoption of the Resolution of H. L. Pinckney, Wise’s Motion against receiving the Petition was in order— This started a new debate which continued till 4. O’Clock, when the house adjourned— I took Jarvis home to his lodgings, and passed the Evening writing—
16. VI:30. Tuesday.

Dr Lovell called this morning for my vote for the election of A. Hamilton Bishop as Pastor of the 2d. Presbyterian Congregation, which I gave him, the election being to be held at 5. O’Clock this afternoon— The Son of Mr Joseph Morton, of Milton and Boston, brought me a Letter from his father— He is a young Lawyer at Boston— At the House— After the reports from Committees, the Resolution of F. O. J. Smith, to print the Letter of W. T. Barry late Postmaster General received on the last Night of the last Session of Congress came up, and Hawes of Kentucky debating it referred to a publication under the name of Smith during the recess of Congress as grossly false— The Speaker called him to order, upon which a debate of two hours arose; and the question was finally taken by yeas and nays, whether the decision of the Speaker should stand as the sense of the house, and decided that it should— I voted against it 159 to 42. Then Hawes declared his acquiesced in the decision of the House, and it was voted that he should have leave to proceed to-morrow— Then the Special order of the day came up— The New-York Fire-Bill in which Stephen C. Phillips made a maiden Speech.— (Mr Alden brought me a pamphlet on the claim of the Heirs of Silas Deane, for the settlement of his accounts) Mr Phillips’s Speech, was of about one hour in favour of the Bill—very sensible and eloquent. Howard of Baltimore came to my seat, and asked my support of a Bill reported by him requesting the discriminating duties upon Belgian vessels.
17. V:45. Wednesday
Ash Wednesday.

After the reading the Journal, and the Reports from the Committee sundry Motions were made to suspend the Rules for the introductions of Resolutions, and for fixing a special order of the day, for certain Bills to-morrow, but they all failed. A joint Resolution authorizing the Governor of Connecticut to cause a monument to the memory of Captain Nathan Hale—was reported by Mr Judson, chairman of the select Committee, read twice and he moved its reference to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union— Vinton of Ohio objects and moves the reference to the Committee of the whole—upon which he makes a Speech—before decision of this question, the order of the day was called, and the House went into Committee of the whole, on the Union, Connor in the Chair upon the New-York fire Bill— Graves of Kentucky makes a Speech against the Bill, in answer to that of Mr Phillips made yesterday—followed by Cushman of New-Hampshire for striking out a proviso—and then by John W. Taylor against the Bill—then by Parker of New-Jersey Cambreleng moves an amendment which is adopted; then followed an altercation between Cambreleng and Hardin.

Darlington brought me a Harrisburg Newspaper with the account of the passage of the Bill, rechartering the Bank of the United States, in the Senate of Pennsylvania 19 to 12. The Serjeant at arms of the Senate, sends a boy to me, for a copy of my Speech upon the three Million Appropriation—which I gave him—
18. VI. Thursday.

Committee of Manufactures—present Denny, Holsey, Judson, Gideon Lee, M’Comas, Adams— Absent Granger Dickerson and Webster— Two Resolutions referred— One for repealing duties, particularly on Coal—and the other for encouraging the cultivation and manufacture of silk— After discussion the Committee adjourned to next Thursday at 11. At the house, after the reports from Committees were received the special order of the day for one hour was taken up— Committee of the whole on the Union, L. Lincoln Chairman on the Bill providing for payment of the Militia employed in the service of U.S. against the Florida Indians— Bill reported to the house with Amendments, adopted, passed to be engrossed and passed. Then the New-York fire Bill was taken up as the special order of the day. Committee of the whole on the Union Connor in the chair— Storer of Ohio, Hiram Hunt and Lane of Indiana make elaborate Speeches in favour of the Bill— (Toucey told me that the Committee on the Judiciary were about to report a Bill, for fixing the boundary of the State of Ohio, giving the Michigan land to that State unanimously, with the exception of him but that there was a proposition to compensate Michigan by an equivalent grant of other land elsewhere—)

Underwood of Kentucky makes a Speech against the fire-bill—followed by Cave Johnson, with a Speech in its favour but against the remission of duties— Then John Reed, and Cambreleng— One Amendment adopted and several others rejected, and the Bill reported to the House with the Amendment— Adjourned after 5 O’Clock— Evening anxious and busy.
19. IV. Friday—

Subscription for Aboriginal Port-Folio of Indian Portraits—to be ten numbers at 2 dollars each— At the House met Andrew Stewart— Reports of Committees received— In the first hour several Bills were taken up out of their order, and passed their Stages— Then the New-York fire Bill was taken up.
20. VI:30. Saturday

Among the Letters received this morning was one from Midshipman Joseph H. Adams on board the U.S. Ship Delaware 74. Hampton Roads just arrived from the Mediterranean, after a cruize of nearly 4 years— She has been expected these three Months, and was quite out of time—there were several enclosures for his mother, brother and Sister— Also a Letter from Lieutt. T. B. Adams at Fort Brooke Tampa Bay, to his mother. I went to the War and Navy Departments— To the bounty Land Office, where I obtained copies of the official printed Regulations, requested by Mr Anthony Collamore of Pembroke, which I enclosed to him— I called at General Macomb’s Office and enquired how to forward to Lieutt. T. B. Adams any Letters—the General said if I would send them to him he would forward them through the Adjutant General— Then at the Navy Department I enquired how to forward a Letter to Midshipman Joseph H. Adams— Mr Dickerson advised to enclose it to Commodore Warrington, Commander at the Navy-Yard Norfolk. He said the Delaware would be immediately refitted and sent to Sea again— The crew would be discharged, and the Officers would receive leave of absence in a few days. I answered the Midshipman’s Letters and wrote to Mr. Anthony Collamore— Judge Randall of the middle district of Florida paid me a morning visit— Also Mr Borden, and Mr Benjamin Cowell of Providence, who leaves the City to-morrow Morning to return home— All my leisure is absorbed in application to one subject— R. M. Johnson told me they would bring up my Resolution next Tuesday but the longer the time that elapses, the more unprepared it seems to me that I shall be.
21. VI. Sunday

I lay half the night awake; the consequence of sitting up till near Midnight, and of intense application of mind to one subject— I attended morning worship at the Presbyterian Church, and heard Mr Gurley, from John 4.18. “For perfect love casteth out fear”— But it was impossible for me to give attention to his discourse— Mr and Mrs Frye and their Son Thomas dined with us and Alexander H. Everett came in after dinner
23. V:45. Tuesday.

At the House, immediately after the reading of the Journal, two Messages were received from the President— The first was announcing the settlement of the controversy with France, with the Correspondence containing the Mediation of Great Britain, and recommending large Appropriations for placing the Country in a state of defence, closing with a quotation from Washington’s farewell Address— Motion was made to lay the Message on the table—and print— I moved a reconsideration of the vote to lay on the table which passed, and that it should be referred to the Committee of foreign Relations, which was agreed to— Then motion to print 10,000 and 25000 copies—the Speaker decided that this motion must lay over a day— Motion to suspend the rules, to take the question this day—carried— Objection made— I supported the motion to print an extra number of the Message. Boon moved 40000—not carried—25000 was carried— The other Message was an answer to a call for French Documents laid on the table— The Speaker then called for Reports from Standing Committees— I enquired whether it was not Petition day— The Speaker said Monday was Petition day— I appealed to the Rule that Petitions should be received on the first day of the Meeting of the House in each week. He found on referring to the rule that it was so and acquiesced. Petitions were called— Several Petitions from Massachusetts Members were received— I presented one from W. Callender referred to the Military Committee—one from Cohasset referred to Committee of Commerce—one from Michillimakinac referred to the same Committee— Then a Petition from Cayuga County New-York, for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia, which started again the Slavery debate which occupied the remainder of the day—
24. V: Wednesday.

Call at the Department of State, to look at the Volume of the Globe Newspaper for the first half-year of 1835 but did not find what I was in search of. I left with Mr Dickins the three pamphlet Session Acts of Congress, in exchange for those he had furnished me with— At the House I found the Clerk reading the Journal— Reports from standing Committees were called andof Ohio presented the report on the contested election, ofGraham of North-Carolina— The report is against Graham, and there is a minority report in his favour reported by Mr W. C. Claiborne the Chairman of the Committee. A debate arose as to the fixing of a time for considering the reports— Mr Graham presented a written communication to the Speaker, asking time to send to North-Carolina for further testimony—
25. VI. Thursday.

Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures—present Dickerson, M’Comas, Gideon Lee, Judson, Holsey, Granger. absent, Denny, Webster— Bill from the Senate authorizing George Whitman to import an iron steamboat in detached parts &c free from duty— I was instructed to report that the Bill should not pass— Bill H.R. 298 with substitute proposed by P. Dickerson, discussed and postponed, Adjourned to Monday 1. March— In the House, instead of calling for Reports from Committees the Speaker called up the question left unfinished yesterday upon the Report of the Committee of Elections in the case ofGraham of North-Carolina— The motions were to fix the day, for taking up the Report— A debate upon the Rules and Orders of the House—was commenced by Bell of Tennessee, answered by Mason of Virginia, and Mann of New York. After the first hour, the Bills on their first and second reading were taken up, and disposed of— Patton called for the Patronage Bill from the Senate— After some discussion the question whether the house would act upon the Bill, was taken by yeas and nays 104 and 104. The Speaker decided in favour of acting— Patton made a Speech in favour of referring the Bill to a Select Committee and not to the Judiciary Committee— Dromgoole moved its reference to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, which was carried without division— Then the New-York fire Bill came up at the third reading— D. J. Pearce makes a diffusive Speech against the Bill— Slashing, right and left, till past 4. O’Clock— Then before he had finished the House adjourned— Pearce brought in John Lowell and the Hartford Convention, Arthur Tappan and abolition— N. Biddle and the Bank of the United States and the like ad infinitum— Evening absorbed in writing till midnight— Received four abolition Petitions—
26. VI:30. Friday— Two feet deep of Snow.

At the House, the unfinished business of the morning hour, was the report of the Committee of Elections against Graham of North Carolina, and the motions to fix days to consider the report— W. B. Shepard, Bynum, and Graham the member discussed the question— Graham insisting upon his claim for time to send to North-Carolina, for further Evidence— The expiration of the hour suspended the debate— Attempts were made to suspend the Rules to call the States for Petitions, and to take up the New-York fire-bill, but they failed— At one O’Clock, private business was taken up and the Bill for the relief ofSmith at the third reading— Owens of Georgia made a Speech of an hour and a half against it and Whittlesey a short one in its favour— Dunlap moved the previous question which was seconded and carried—the Bill was passed by yeas and nays 104 toThen the house went into Committee of the whole. S. C. Phillips Chairman—sundry private Bills were reported to the House—one for the relief of James Latham was somewhat debated— Vinton moved an Amendment, opposed by May, and Rice Garland, but the Amendment was carried— The house adjourned just at four O’Clock, and L. Jarvis rode home with me— In the Evening Russell Freeman called and spent an hour with me. He has been passing several weeks at Raleigh and at Washington, North Carolina, where he has two nephews Edmund, and David Freeman, sons of his brother Jonathan Freeman, who died in that State last November, having been many years settled in North-Carolina— His nephews are White whigs— Freeman told me that Mr Webster told him this week that it was J. C. Calhoun who procured his Freeman’s being turned out of his Office of Collector of New-Bedford— Mary was unwell this day and Evening—
27. VI. Saturday.

At the Pension Office, and applied for copies of the papers of Leavitt Lane, a Revolutionary Pensioner, requested by Letter from Fisher A. Kingsbury, Weymouth— At General Macomb’s Office, and left a packet for Lieutt. T. B. Adams. At the House, I obtained the Papers of Rebecca Sampson—to be called up and referred on Monday— Russell Freeman asked admission into the House, without the Bar—for which I asked leave of the Speaker Polk, who consented; if I would take the responsibility— A man by the name of Jagger, from Long-Island said he would call and see me at my house at 7. O’Clock this Evening. Immediately after the reading of the Journal, the Speaker called up the unfinished business of the yesterday Morning hour. The report of the Committee of Elections, on the North-Carolina election, contested the motion for allowing time requested by Mr Graham to take further testimony, was discussed by the Chairman of the Committee Claiborne, the reporter of the Majority report Boyd, Reynolds of Illinois, and others, continued by a suspension of the Rules, a second hour still without decision— At 2. O’Clock the orders of the day—private business were taken up— Twelve Bills were referred to the Committee of the whole. S. C. Phillips in the Chair, all but one reported without Amendment—progress reported, and leave asked to sit again on that— Then the House went into the Committee of the whole upon sundry other Bills. Daniel Wardwell in the Chair they were reported to the House with two or three exception—postponed for further consideration— The House adjourned at half past four— L. Jarvis rode home with me.

Caroline de Wint dined with us, and Mr Jagger came in the Evening, and sat with me about an hour— He put several questions about the lies respecting the East Room—the West India trade and the charges of extravaganze against me—
28. VI:15. Sunday.
At the Presbyterian Church—heard Mr Gurley from Romans

After the Sermon he read a notice of a Meeting of the Members of the Congregation next Wednesday, to make choice of a Minister, the late Call of Mr Bishop, has been declined, which I heard with great mortification.

29. Feby. Monday— After the adjournment of the House of Representatives, I came out of the House at the right hand door as I came out the Speaker James K. Polk was just before me passing across the entry from the Hall, to the Speaker’s chamber— As he was about halfway across Henry A. Wise came up to him, stooped down and looked into his face, holding up his right hand and pointing his finger to him, and said “I want to say to you that you are a damn’d coward—now take that insult, and pocket it.” I think he added— I say it to you personally— Mr Polk passed on to the Speaker’s Chamber, without noticing Wise, or turning to the right hand; or the left— There were several persons within hearing but I did not mark who they were— Mr Wise immediately turned away towards the Rotunda—

Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures—present Adams, Denny Dickerson, Granger, Holsey, Judson, Lee— Absent M’Comas and Webster— Letters to W. C. Calhoun and one to Mr Judson, urging the collection of information respecting the culture and manufacture of silk— Holsey objects as impairing the compromise Then the recommendation of the Secretary of the Treasury, to take off the duties upon certain Articles, not impairing the compromise was discussed and postponed; adjourned to Wednesday Morning. At the House Petition day— Lawlers appeal from the Speaker’s decision, that the Instruction proposed by him to be annexed to the Petition for the abolition of Slavery—presented by me, was not in order, was discussed— Lawler made two or three Speeches— He was answered by Mercer, and Vinton and replied to boyd supported by W. B. Sheppard— Lawler finished by withdrawing his appeal. Petitions were called I presented the papers of the Petition ofA Petition fromin the County of Barnstable—a Petition of 111 Ladies in Hingham, and one of about 30 Men of Hingham for the abolition of Slavery and the Slave trade in the district of Columbia, which were referred of course to the select Committee appointed at the motion of H. L. Pinckney— A multitude of other Petitions to the same effect— When the call of Petitions came to Virginia J. M. Patton presented Resolutions of the Legislature of Virginia, upon the Abolition subject and moved that they should be referred to the Committee on the District of Columbia with Instructions— The Speaker decided that this motion was not in order, the Virginia Resolutions being already referred to the Select Committee—from this decision Patton appealed, and made a Speech— Wise made a furious one, till he was ordered to sit down by the Speaker— J. M. Mason moved that he should be permitted to proceed which was refused by the House by yeas and nays.— Holsey attempted to make a Speech; but Pinckney moved the Previous Question on the Speaker’s decision; which was carried by yeas and naysand the decision of the Chair was sustained.
